education.institution: Physics department, Technical University of Munich (TUM)
Master of Science (dual degree) in Materials Science exploiting Large-Scale Facilities, LMU
Bachelor of Science in Chemistry, Sun Yat-Sen (Zhong Shan) University (SYSU, top 10 universities in China)

basics.name: Juanjuan Huang
basics.label: Assistant Beamline Scientist
basics.summary: A multidisciplinary scientist with a Bachelor’s degree in chemistry, Master’s degree materials science and PhD degree in physics, currently working as a beamline scientist at the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory. My expertise lies in developing synchrotron techniques, particularly X-ray spectroscopy and spectral imaging, and applying them to fundamental scientific research.

work.name: Assistant beamline scientist – the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laborotary
work.summary: Group leader: Dr. Shelly Kelly. Develop X-ray technologies on the most brilliant X-ray synchrotron source in the world. Maintain instrumentation/hardware/software related to X-ray spectroscopy techniques. Explore scientific usages of X-ray spectroscopy techniques in diverse fields such as chemistry, biology, medicines, physics. Support large facility users from acdemia and industry.

work.name: Postdoctoral Appointee – the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laborotary
work.summary: Supervisor: Dr. George Sterbinsky; Group leader: Dr. Shelly Kelly, Research project entitled Resolving Capacity Fade in Li-Ion Batteries with Single-Shot Chemical Mapping, Implemented dispersive X-ray absorption spectroscopy (DXAS) for fast XANES-imaging on beamline ID25, APS and applied to Li-ion batteries.

work.name: Doctoral researcher – Department of physics, Technical
work.summary: Supervisors: Dr. Martin Dierolf, Prof. Dr. Franz Pfeiffer， Research group: Chair of biomedical physics (E17)， Research topic: X-ray absorption spectroscopy at the Munich Compact Light Source.

work.name: Short-term research scholar - Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource (SSRL)
work.summary: Supervisor: Dr. Yijin Liu， Worked on BL 6-2c (transmission X-ray microscope), Hands-on experience on 3d XANES imaging and data analysis

work.name: Master’s researcher - European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF)
work.summary: Supervisor: Dr. Marius Retegan; Group leader: Dr. Pieter Glatzel (beamline ID 26), Master’s thesis entitled: The Electronic Structure of Mononuclear Manganese Compounds: Experimental and Theoretical Insights from X-Ray Absorption Spectroscopy and Resonant Inelastic X-Ray Scattering, Internship: XANES, valence-to-core XES simulation of transitional metal containing complexes using ORCA package.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

talks.title: Conference: International Symposium on Compact Synchrotron X-ray
talks.summary: International Symposium on Compact Synchrotron X-ray, Sources 2024, Dispersive X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy at the Munich Compact Light Source (MuCLS) and the Advanced Photon Source (APS)

talks.title: Conference: X-ray Spectroscopy beyond Beamlines
talks.summary: Conference: X-ray Spectroscopy beyond Beamlines, Dispersive X-ray absorption spectroscopy with an inverse Compton source

talks.title: Webinar: Global XAS Journal Club
talks.summary: Webinar: Global XAS Journal Club, Energy Dispersive X-ray absorption spectroscopy at the Munich Compact Light Source

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
